message_1: A spaceship travels through space at a velocity of 0.8c. If its rest mass is 5000 kg, what is its relativistic mass as seen by an observer on Earth?
message_2:
To find the relativistic mass of the spaceship, we can use the following equation:

m_rel = m_rest / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where m_rel is the relativistic mass, m_rest is the rest mass, v is the velocity of the spaceship, and c is the speed of light.

Given the rest mass (m_rest) of 5000 kg and the velocity (v) of 0.8c, we can plug in the values and solve for the relativistic mass:

m_rel = 5000 kg / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)

m_rel = 5000 kg / sqrt(1 - 0.64)

m_rel = 5000 kg / sqrt(0.36)

m_rel = 5000 kg / 0.6

So, the relativistic mass of the spaceship as seen by an observer on Earth is approximately 8333.33 kg.
